context: The mineralization result lays within the range of what was found in Vergara-Fernández et al. (2011a) for the elimination of n-hexane in a biofilter inoculated with Fusarium solani during the growth period of biomass, from their results, a 70% n-hexane mineralization can be calculated.Continuous culture operation The three bioreactors showed a very reproducible performance in terms of n-pentane removal and CO2 production. The three bioreactors reached an EC of 250(±20) g m−3 h−1 by the second day of operation, rapidly increasing up to an EC of 650(±50) g m−3 h−1 after 11 days of operation (Fig. 3b). This rapid increase in EC was likely due to the previous adaptation of the fungal biomass to the biodegradation of n-pentane and to the high density of the aerial biomass present in the bioreactors. Biomass increases only 2 g L−1 from the onset of the continuous gas fed, reaching 89.3(±3.5) g L−1 dry support. This low growth is a consequence of the limited amount of nutrients supplied at the end of the batch culture, a condition purposely selected to promote carbon mineralization rather than its incorporation to biomass.
